assignedDRGDescription: Septicemia or Severe Sepsis w/o MV >96 Hours w MCC
clinicalNotes: 78-year-old female admitted via ED with severe sepsis secondary to UTI. Lactic acid 4.2 mmol/L, WBC 22.1, creatinine 3.8 (baseline 1.1). Required vasopressor support for 18 hours. IV antibiotics (meropenem), aggressive fluid resuscitation. AKI with organ dysfunction. Could not be managed outpatient given hemodynamic instability and organ failure.
agentSummary: Medical necessity criteria for inpatient admission are met. Patient Margaret Johnson presented with clinical severity and service intensity supporting inpatient-level care. No adverse findings identified.

assignedDRGDescription: Kidney & Urinary Tract Infections w/o MCC

primaryDiagnosis.description: Urinary tract infection, site not specified

clinicalNotes: 65-year-old male presented to ED with dysuria and urinary frequency x 3 days. Afebrile. UA positive for nitrites and leukocyte esterase. Urine culture pending. Vitals stable throughout. Tolerating PO intake. Ambulatory. No signs of systemic infection. Received one dose IV antibiotic in ED then transitioned to oral ciprofloxacin. Could have been managed as outpatient with oral antibiotics.
treatmentsProvided: IV ceftriaxone x1 dose in ED

medNecessityFindings.description: No hospital-level services identified: no IV medications required, no ICU care, no surgical procedures, no telemetry, no supplemental oxygen, and no isolation precautions. Services provided could potentially be delivered at a lower level of care.
medNecessityFindings.recommendation: Review whether oral medications, outpatient monitoring, or observation status would have been appropriate. Document any services requiring inpatient-level nursing or monitoring intensity.

medNecessityFindings.description: Patient received only a single IV medication dose before transitioning to oral therapy. A single IV dose in the ED does not typically justify inpatient admission unless other intensity criteria are met.
medNecessityFindings.recommendation: Document clinical rationale for why ongoing IV therapy or inpatient monitoring was required beyond the initial IV dose. Consider whether ED observation or outpatient follow-up was appropriate.

medNecessityFindings.description: Clinical documentation suggests condition is manageable in an outpatient setting. Patient is tolerating oral intake, ambulatory, and hemodynamically stable. Inpatient admission criteria may not be met.
medNecessityFindings.recommendation: Consider retrospective review for observation or outpatient status. Ensure documentation clearly supports why inpatient-level care was required despite stable presentation.

medNecessityFindings.description: Clinical documentation contains language suggesting the condition did not require inpatient admission. This significantly weakens medical necessity justification and increases denial risk on payer review.
medNecessityFindings.recommendation: Query attending physician to clarify medical necessity. If inpatient care was truly required, documentation must be amended to remove contradictory language and add specific clinical criteria supporting admission. CDI query recommended.

agentSummary: Medical necessity criteria for inpatient admission are NOT met. 4 findings identified (2 critical). Recommended level of care: Inpatient. Estimated denial exposure: $20,721.6. Denial risk: 100%.

assignedDRGDescription: Heart Failure & Shock w MCC

primaryDiagnosis.description: Acute on chronic combined systolic and diastolic heart failure

clinicalNotes: 81-year-old female with acute decompensated CHF. BNP 2840 pg/mL. CXR bilateral pleural effusions, pulmonary edema. O2 sat 84% on room air, required BiPAP then high-flow NC. IV furosemide drip with strict I&O monitoring. Weight loss 10 lbs over 3 days. Echocardiogram EF 20%. Required continuous telemetry for arrhythmia monitoring. Inpatient admission clearly necessary for respiratory failure and hemodynamic monitoring.
agentSummary: Medical necessity criteria for inpatient admission are met. Patient Dorothy Adams presented with clinical severity and service intensity supporting inpatient-level care. No adverse findings identified.

assignedDRGDescription: Percutaneous Cardiovascular Proc w Drug-Eluting Stent w MCC

primaryDiagnosis.description: Atherosclerotic heart disease of native coronary artery

clinicalNotes: 71-year-old male admitted for elective diagnostic cardiac catheterization for stable angina on exertion. No acute symptoms on day of admission. Cath revealed 60% LAD and 40% RCA stenosis — non-obstructive, no stent placed. Patient stable post-procedure, ambulating same day. Tolerating PO diet. No chest pain, no hemodynamic instability. Diagnostic cardiac catheterization is routinely performed as an outpatient procedure. No complications requiring overnight observation beyond standard recovery.

medNecessityFindings.description: Elective admission for diagnostic evaluation without a therapeutic procedure or ICU-level care. Elective diagnostic workups and monitoring can typically be performed in an outpatient or observation setting.
medNecessityFindings.recommendation: Review admission criteria. Elective admissions should have a clear therapeutic intent. If the admission is for pre-procedural evaluation, document the planned procedure and medical necessity for inpatient pre-op stay.

medNecessityFindings.description: For this condition, payers typically require documentation of failed outpatient therapy before approving inpatient admission. No documentation of failed oral antibiotics, outpatient treatment failure, or clinical progression despite outpatient management.
medNecessityFindings.recommendation: Document any prior outpatient treatment attempts and why they were insufficient. If the patient was directly admitted, document clinical severity that precluded outpatient trial. This documentation strengthens medical necessity and reduces denial risk.

agentSummary: Medical necessity criteria for inpatient admission are NOT met. 4 findings identified (1 critical). Recommended level of care: Observation. Estimated denial exposure: $73,610. Denial risk: 100%.

assignedDRGDescription: Bronchitis & Asthma w/o CC/MCC

primaryDiagnosis.description: Moderate persistent asthma with acute exacerbation

clinicalNotes: 42-year-old female presented with wheezing and dyspnea. Peak flow 70% predicted on arrival, improved to 85% after one nebulizer treatment. O2 sat 95% on room air. No accessory muscle use. Able to speak in full sentences. Responded to standard nebulizer therapy within 2 hours. Transitioned to metered dose inhaler and oral prednisone. Ambulating without distress. Tolerating oral intake. Meets observation criteria but does not meet inpatient admission criteria — expected recovery within 24 hours with standard bronchodilator therapy.

assignedDRGDescription: Resp System Diagnosis w Ventilator Support >96 Hours
clinicalNotes: 73-year-old male admitted with bilateral pneumonia progressing to ARDS. Intubated on day 1 for P/F ratio 85. Required mechanical ventilation for 192 hours. PEEP 14, FiO2 60-80%. ICU stay with vasopressor support. Tracheostomy on day 10. Weaned to trach collar day 13. Severe illness requiring continuous ICU-level care. Inpatient admission clearly medically necessary — life-threatening respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation.
agentSummary: Medical necessity criteria for inpatient admission are met. Patient William Davis presented with clinical severity and service intensity supporting inpatient-level care. No adverse findings identified.

assignedDRGDescription: Esophagitis, Gastroenteritis & Misc Digestive Disorders w/o MCC
clinicalNotes: 48-year-old female presented with 24 hours of nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Vitals stable in ED. Mild dehydration. Received 2L IV fluid in ED with symptom improvement. Tolerating clear liquids by hour 4 in ED. No fever, no bloody stools. Abdominal exam benign — soft, non-tender. Labs unremarkable except mild BUN elevation. Patient could have been managed in observation or discharged from ED after rehydration. Symptoms resolved rapidly with IV fluids.

assignedDRGDescription: Acute Myocardial Infarction, Discharged Alive w MCC
clinicalNotes: 62-year-old male presented with crushing chest pain, ST elevation V1-V4. Troponin I 12.4. Emergent PCI with drug-eluting stent to LAD. Post-PCI EF 45%. Required continuous telemetry, IV heparin drip, dual antiplatelet therapy. ICU observation first 24 hours. Inpatient admission clearly necessary for acute STEMI requiring emergent catheterization and post-procedural monitoring.
treatmentsProvided: Emergent PCI with DES to LAD
agentSummary: Medical necessity criteria for inpatient admission are met. Patient Charles Wilson presented with clinical severity and service intensity supporting inpatient-level care. No adverse findings identified.

assignedDRGDescription: Cellulitis w/o MCC
clinicalNotes: 59-year-old male with cellulitis of right lower leg. Area of erythema 8cm x 5cm, non-fluctuant, no abscess. Afebrile. WBC 11.8. No streaking lymphangitis. Patient ambulatory. Could tolerate oral antibiotics. No failed outpatient oral antibiotics prior to admission. No signs of systemic toxicity. Cellulitis limited in extent without complicating features. Oral antibiotics with outpatient follow-up would be appropriate initial management per IDSA guidelines.
agentSummary: Medical necessity criteria for inpatient admission are met. Patient Richard Thompson presented with clinical severity and service intensity supporting inpatient-level care. No adverse findings identified.

assignedDRGDescription: Intracranial Hemorrhage or Cerebral Infarction w MCC

secondaryDiagnoses.description: Hemiplegia, unspecified affecting right dominant side

clinicalNotes: 79-year-old female with acute left MCA ischemic stroke. NIHSS 14. tPA administered within window. Required neuro ICU monitoring for 48 hours. Developed right-sided hemiplegia and dysphagia. NPO with NG tube feeding. Continuous telemetry for atrial fibrillation management. Intravenous heparin drip. PT/OT/ST daily. Complex stroke requiring ICU-level neuro monitoring, airway protection, and thrombolytic management.
agentSummary: Medical necessity criteria for inpatient admission are met. Patient Barbara Anderson presented with clinical severity and service intensity supporting inpatient-level care. No adverse findings identified.

assignedDRGDescription: Syncope & Collapse
clinicalNotes: 55-year-old male with single episode of vasovagal syncope. No prodrome of chest pain, palpitations, or SOB. Witnessed event — stood up quickly, felt lightheaded, lost consciousness for 10 seconds. No seizure activity, no incontinence. GCS 15 on arrival. CT head negative. ECG normal sinus rhythm. Troponin negative x2. Orthostatic vitals negative. Neurological exam normal. Echocardiogram normal EF 60%. This is a low-risk syncope that meets observation criteria. No high-risk features (no cardiac history, normal ECG, negative troponins). Could be evaluated with 12-24 hour telemetry in observation.

assignedDRGDescription: GI Hemorrhage w MCC
clinicalNotes: 72-year-old female admitted with melena and hemoglobin drop from 12.1 to 7.2. Required 4 units PRBC transfusion. EGD revealed actively bleeding gastric ulcer treated with epinephrine injection and bipolar cautery. INR 4.8, platelets 68K, DIC with elevated D-dimer. Required ICU-level monitoring for hemodynamic stability during active bleed. IV PPI drip. Hemoglobin stabilized post-procedure. Clearly meets inpatient criteria — active GI hemorrhage with coagulopathy and hemodynamic compromise.
agentSummary: Medical necessity criteria for inpatient admission are met. Patient Susan Clark presented with clinical severity and service intensity supporting inpatient-level care. No adverse findings identified.

assignedDRGDescription: Chest Pain
clinicalNotes: 52-year-old male admitted with atypical chest pain. Non-exertional, reproducible with palpation. No diaphoresis, no radiation. ECG normal sinus rhythm, no ST changes. Serial troponins negative x3 at 0, 3, and 6 hours. HEART score 2 (low risk). Stress test next morning — negative for ischemia. Normal echocardiogram. Chest pain determined to be musculoskeletal. This is a classic observation-level workup. HEART score <3 with negative troponins can be safely ruled out in observation status per ACC/AHA guidelines.

assignedDRGDescription: Pulmonary Embolism w MCC

primaryDiagnosis.description: Other pulmonary embolism with acute cor pulmonale

secondaryDiagnoses.description: Acute embolism of unspecified deep veins of lower extremity

clinicalNotes: 58-year-old female with massive bilateral PE on CT angiography. Hemodynamically unstable — systolic BP 78, HR 128. RV strain on echo with RV/LV ratio 1.4. Troponin elevated at 0.48 ng/mL. Received systemic tPA (alteplase) for massive PE. ICU admission for 48 hours post-thrombolysis monitoring. Heparin drip followed by transition to warfarin. Required supplemental oxygen throughout stay. Clearly meets inpatient criteria — life-threatening PE with hemodynamic instability requiring thrombolysis.
agentSummary: Medical necessity criteria for inpatient admission are met. Patient Jennifer White presented with clinical severity and service intensity supporting inpatient-level care. No adverse findings identified.

assignedDRGDescription: Renal Failure w/o CC/MCC
clinicalNotes: 68-year-old male admitted for CKD stage 4 evaluation and vascular access planning for dialysis. Elective admission. Creatinine stable at 4.2 (baseline 4.0). No acute symptoms — no edema, no uremia symptoms. Vitals stable. Ambulatory. Underwent AV fistula creation (outpatient procedure). Renal diet education. Could have been managed entirely outpatient — AV fistula creation is commonly performed as outpatient surgery, and CKD education does not require inpatient admission.

assignedDRGDescription: Septicemia or Severe Sepsis w/o MV >96 Hours w MCC

primaryDiagnosis.description: Sepsis due to Methicillin susceptible Staphylococcus aureus

clinicalNotes: 64-year-old female with MSSA bacteremia progressing to septic shock. Required intubation for respiratory failure, vasopressor support (norepinephrine and vasopressin), and CRRT for AKI. Multi-organ failure. ICU for 3 days. Extubated day 3, weaned off vasopressors. Source: infected central line from prior hospitalization. Line removed, IV nafcillin initiated. Clearly medically necessary — multi-organ failure with septic shock requiring ICU-level interventions.
agentSummary: Medical necessity criteria for inpatient admission are met. Patient Mary Taylor presented with clinical severity and service intensity supporting inpatient-level care. No adverse findings identified.

assignedDRGDescription: Hypertension w/o MCC
clinicalNotes: 58-year-old male presented with BP 198/108. Asymptomatic — no headache, no chest pain, no visual changes, no dyspnea. No end-organ damage on workup: creatinine normal, troponin negative, CT head normal, ECG unchanged from baseline. This is hypertensive urgency (not emergency) — no acute target organ damage. BP reduced to 160/95 with oral amlodipine in ED. Guidelines recommend gradual outpatient BP reduction over 24-48 hours for hypertensive urgency without end-organ damage. Inpatient admission not warranted.

assignedDRGDescription: Hip & Femur Procedures Except Major Joint w CC

primaryDiagnosis.description: Fracture of unspecified part of neck of right femur

clinicalNotes: 84-year-old female with displaced right femoral neck fracture after fall. Underwent ORIF with dynamic hip screw on day 1. Required post-operative pain management with PCA morphine. PT initiated day 1 post-op. Unable to weight-bear independently. Required daily wound care and anticoagulation for DVT prophylaxis. Surgical admission clearly medically necessary — displaced hip fracture requires operative fixation and post-operative inpatient rehabilitation.

assignedDRGDescription: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease w MCC
clinicalNotes: 67-year-old male with severe COPD exacerbation. O2 sat 82% on room air. ABG: pH 7.31, pCO2 58, pO2 52. Required BiPAP for 48 hours. IV methylprednisolone and continuous nebulizers. Significant hypercarbic respiratory failure. Could not maintain adequate oxygenation without mechanical ventilatory support. Inpatient admission medically necessary — acute respiratory failure requiring non-invasive ventilation cannot be safely managed in observation or outpatient setting.
agentSummary: Medical necessity criteria for inpatient admission are met. Patient Robert Wright presented with clinical severity and service intensity supporting inpatient-level care. No adverse findings identified.

assignedDRGDescription: Simple Pneumonia & Pleurisy w MCC
clinicalNotes: 74-year-old female with community-acquired pneumonia. O2 sat 88% on room air, requiring 4L NC. CXR right lower lobe consolidation. WBC 18.2. CURB-65 score 3 (high severity). Required IV antibiotics (ceftriaxone + azithromycin) and continuous supplemental oxygen. Unable to maintain adequate oxygenation without support. Pneumonia with respiratory failure meeting inpatient admission criteria per ATS/IDSA guidelines (CURB-65 >= 3).
